Moment of inertia is calculated as the integral of r^2 dm over the entire mass, but let's just simplify this to the distance from [a,b].  An integral is essentially F(b)-F(a).  (This premise makes more sense drawn out, but I assume you know what an integral looks like, and how it functions.)  Imagine a ring that, at any point, is distance b away from the center.  Now, since the ring theoretically has no value for F(a) because there's no mass there, its moment of inertia is just F(b)-0.  The marble however, does have mass at point a, thus it's moment of inertia is F(b)-F(a).  Therefore, the ring is going to have a larger moment of inertia than the marble will.

Static friction does not slow objects down, it merely prevents them from moving in the first place, which is necessary for the round objects to roll instead of just sliding. Kinetic friction is what slows objects down, and if you paid attention, the example specifically did not have kinetic friction, and only static friction. If there was kinetic friction, then part of the potential energy would be lost to heat due to kinetic friction, and you'd suddenly have a complicated equation to figure out how much the kinetic friction slowed down the box to determine whether the ball and possibly the ring beat it.

Rolling and sliding use different types of friction, static and kinetic, and it was specified that there is static, but no kinetic. In real life everything has both kinds of friction, so this mythical ramp they cooked up is pretty counter-intuitive, I agree.

I know, but even on the ramp with the stated qualities it does not work: w.l.o.g. we can assume equal masses and (for the problem to make sense) equal static friction coefficients. Thus they experience equal friction forces. If the block should move at all we have to demand that the ramp is steep enough for the resulting tangential force to be larger than the friction force. The friction force and part of the tangential force (equal in magnitude with the friction) form a couple of forces which is the maximum torque to accelerate the ring's rotation. But there is some (little) tangential force left (since it has to be larger than the friction) which accelerates the ring into a sliding motion right from the start. The static friction immediately disappears and the rolling stipulation is no longer met. Therefore the ring slides too down the ramp without losing any energy into rotation and finishes together with the oder bodies at the same time.

Why would you assume they're all the same mass and all have equal friction coefficients?The friction value depends on both surfaces, not just the ramp, and they all experience the same acceleration from gravity regardless of mass, right?

Right, (w.l.o.g. means without loss of generality) it does not matter which mass they have in the same way as with (frictionless = no air resistance) falling bodies. All the forces scale with mass in both (the accelerating and the decelerating) directions. But since I wanted to talk about and compare forces (without mentioning all the time that their magnitudes are according to their masses, etc) we can w.l.o.g. assume equal masses.  Now to the friction coefficient. The whole  enterprise of asking which one finishes first becomes quite pointless (=didactically worthless) if the (boundary) conditions for the bodies to compare vary to an extent that they are completely incomparable. Of course there could be differences but then one is equally entitled to say that the friction coefficient for the box is bigger than the ring 's and and the air (resistance) is thinner for the ball and so on.

The static friction doesn't do any work in this example though, so you can stack the parameters to allow rolling without slipping and still show the difference in translational kinetic energy between the rotating and non-rotating bodies.
That's the catch: rolling without slipping means sticking for the box!

So make the box's friction lower. They have different interface areas anyway so they wouldn't have equal friction forces even if they were all the same material. What matters is that they have the same potential energy to start, and no energy leaves the system (so you're right they should have the same mass). The static friction forces can be whatever you want to get the desired behavior though.

That's a common fallacy, but the interface area does not matter. The masses don't matter. It even does not matter whether they have the same potential energy or not (for the question at hand, which is in what order do the bodies arrive.) The only thing that matters is whether the given boundary conditions allow rolling and therefore the "slower" round objects or not. The answer is, they do not! The right (not less artificial) boundary conditions would be: no friction (at all) for the box and high (eg. infinite) friction for the round objects. (Not even necessary to distinguish the kinds of friction)  But that would not have come as a real bombshell. (I figure they messed this up deliberately to keep the viewer interested and to stupefy with the results)

The acceleration of the earth would be ever so slightly different, but the acceleration of the bodies themselves doesn't depend on their mass. F(gravity) = G*m*M/R^2, and F = ma, you put them together you get ma = G*m*M/R^2. m cancels, so the acceleration of the object is independent of m, the mass of the object. It depends only on M, the mass of the earth. Would they hit the ground at exactly the same time? Probably not, but they do go exactly the same speed relative to each other. If you wanted to calculate the exact difference you would have to take into account the tiny bumps and unevenness of the ground, the fact there's only one earth and they're both pulling it, and their gravitational pull on each other.

Lol I see what you did there.

M*r^2 is the moment of a single point of mass about an axis. To get the moment of a solid object, you need to "build" the object from an infinite number of those points and add together all of their moments. That's what integrals are for. Depending on the shape you build, you end up getting a different constant out front, for a sphere it's 2/5.

You have to break down the marble into an infinite number of infinitesimal rings.  Each of those rings will have a mass per unit thickness of 4*ρ*pi*r*sqrt(R^2-r^2) (where R is the total radius of the marble and ρ is the density), because the height would be 2*sqrt(R^2-r^2) as you can see by considering a circular cross-section.  So the moment of inertia per unit thickness of each ring will be 4*ρ*pi*r^3*sqrt(R^2-r^2).  Integrating by parts*, you get -4*ρ*pi*r^2*(R^2-r^2)^(3/2)/3 - 8*ρ*pi*(R^2-r^2)^(5/2)/15 from 0 to R, which comes to 8*ρ*pi*R^5/15.  Now, the mass is going to be m = 4*pi*ρ*R^3/3 just by the properties of the sphere, so this is 2/5 * m * R^2.  (*Integration by parts is using the identity (uv)' = u'v + v'u to find the antiderivative of something expressed as u'v.  In this case, u would be (R^2 - r^2)^(3/2), for which u' would be -3*r*sqrt(R^2 - r^2).)

let me reply to all teh confused ppl here.  A box can slide (kinetic friction) or stand (static friction). A ring can slide, stand or roll (rolling resistance).  The static friction is higher than kinetic one - that is why at the start of dragging something takes you need an extra push.  If the force on an object is lesser than static friction, the object is motionless. If the force on an object is higher/equal than static friction, the object is moving with kinetic friction.  To support rolling the surface must have rolling resistance. Rolling resistance is less than kinetic friction.  In our case motion friction is zero and the force is higher than static friction - because the box moves. That leaves for the ring options to slide or roll, but it can't roll - rolling resistance is zero.  Much like the ring will not start rolling on the flat frictionless surface under lateral force (say, magnet, or wind), it will not start rolling down the ramp. If the force is strong enough to overcome static resistance, there is no reason for the bottom point of the ring (the contact point) stay still - the magnet affects it as much as it affects any other point of the ring.  To put it in other way, imagine the ring started rotating, even a tiny-tiny bit. Since kinetic friction is zero, immediately the ring is having infinite slippage - and the bottom point of it never can be affected by static friction again, leaving its angular speed on infinitely small value.

Anyways, at 00:15, she says that you "let go" blah blah whatever...I actually had to go back to find a quote like this, because what I'm about to say is how I initially made sense of the video in my own mind, and her "let go" statement might be an assumption she/her team also made, just without explaining to the viewer. Now, I'm not a physics major/professional, at best I've taken some undergraduate-level courses, so I would love a civil, respectful case against what I'm about to say if I am wrong about anything, and would also appreciate any feedback if I happen to be right on anything else.  So, say it takes, I don't know, 0.100 seconds to have let go of these items, and let's call that time T1, with T0 = 0.000 seconds being when the hands are holding these items in place, say from the side of the object most-downward along the ramp. At T0, the normal force on the objects by the hands is equal and opposite to grav. force, thus net force (with respect to normal + grav.) is zero and the objects aren't going anywhere (yes I'm simplifying this, I know gravity acts downwards and that the ramp/normal force is at an angle). Between time T0 and T1, the hands are pulling away from the objects perfectly in the direction of intended motion, which is actively reducing that normal force, thus shifting the net force (net between normal + grav.) from zero to some magnitude greater than zero. Of course, there are still forces due to friction, and so as long as the sum of normal and grav. is less than the frictional force needed to move, there is no motion.  However, in the case of the ring/marble, this "growing" net (w.r.t normal+grav.) force only needs to exceed rolling resistance to start rolling, and as mentioned by some people, rolling friction is less than static friction, and so these two items should start rolling before enough "growing net force" exceeds static friction to allow for slippage. Now, in the case of the block, this "growing net force" between time T0/T1 actually does need to exceed static friction, since rolling isn't going to occur and the only way it will move will be due by sliding, and so gravity will eventually overpower static friction because the hand being pulled away will at some point be providing a low enough normal force that static friction isn't enough to hold the block in place.  Under this argument, the rolling objects would roll first without slipping, and the block object would slide. From that point, any arguments made about which one "wins the race" or whatever probably correctly apply as stated in the video. I think the distinction between what I am saying and what some people have posted above me in this thread, is mainly that some other people assume the items are moving due to a single given initial force (gravity) being applied for all items. If that were the case, then the force required to overcome static friction and get the block moving would most certainly cause slippage on the round objects. However, my argument takes into account the small fraction of a time when the hand is being pulled away, which actively reduces normal force and slowly builds up the force working against friction. It isn't a single given initial force applied to these objects, it's a progressive reduction of normal force that allows for rolling.  Now, I could be wrong. Please correct me if I'm wrong. In reality, there is a lot more that could be said; fortunately, this is supposed to be an idealized case. But I would love to hear what anyone would have to say, if anyone is still around to even respond to this.  As a side note (feel free to ignore this paragraph, it adds nothing to my case, it's just a side note), technically T1 for the block would be a bit later than the T1's for the ring/marble (at least on the scale of milliseconds), because if it requires more of a tug on it to get moving (since static friction is larger than rolling friction), then the hand needs to be "pulled away" a bit more for normal force to be reduced enough. So the part of the video that seems wrong to me is the implication that all 3 items can be let go at the same time and correspond with all 3 items starting to move at the same time. I think either they would all begin to move at a different time if let go simultaneously, or they would have to be let go at different times to start moving at the same time, though to be fair, this time difference is most likely pretty damn negligible.

Yes. If you can do integrals, you can get it for yourself by integrating the moment of inertia formula over a sphere. It's not m*r^2 because that only applies for a theoretical point mass, and a sphere is a continuous object.

I scrolled down about five screens looking for a comment like this just to show off.  (I need to get a life.)  The very very short answer is yes, that's a constant for balls (not spheres; spheres are hollow) of uniform density.  The almost-as-short answer is that most (in fact, nearly all) of the mass is closer to the axis of rotation than r, so that mass counts for less.  That doesn't get you to 2/5, though.  For the real answer, think of the ball as a series of rings.  From here on out, we'll pretend the entire radius is 1 because units are arbitrary and it makes the math easier; since units are essentially arbitrary we can do this.  Now that we're not using that letter anymore, we'll call the radius of each ring r.  Now, let's say we've chopped up the ball thinly enough that the thickness of each ring is negligible, so we can treat it as a cylinder.  (The ring in the video's example got this treatment.)  The mass of that ring will be proportional to the surface area of that cylinder, which is 2*pi*r*h, where h is the height of the cylinder.  By the properties of the ball, h = 2*sqrt(1-r^2) (think of the edge of the cylinder as a chord on a circular cross-section, and you can see how this follows from the Pythagorean theorem).  So the surface area of the cylinder is 4*pi*r*sqrt(1-r^2).  We'll pretend for now that the constant of proportionality is 1 (again, units are essentially arbitrary, so we can do this), so we can say that that is the mass per unit thickness of the "ring."  (Note that this makes the mass of the whole marble 4*pi/3.)   So now for each infinitesimal cylinder we have that the moment of inertia per unit thickness is 4*pi*r^3*sqrt(1-r^2).  Here it gets a bit tricky - the trick is something called integration by parts, which is the converse of something called the product rule.  The product rule means, essentially, if you have a rectangle, and you know how quickly the sides are changing, you can treat the change of the whole rectangle as the sum of the change in each side by the current length of the other.  (That is, two infinitesimal rectangles - since the corner square is infinitesimal by infinitesimal, it vanishes in comparison.)  That is, you can express the derivative of a product as the sum of the former by the derivative of the latter and the latter by the derivative of the former.  By the same token, when you have an antiderivative of something that can be expressed as the product of an antiderivative and a derivative, you can treat it as one of the two summands in the product rule, and express the antiderivative as a difference.  In this case (pulling out the constant 4*pi), the derivative is r*sqrt(1-r^2), which is the derivative of (1-r^2)^(3/2)/3, and the antiderivative is r^2, which is the antiderivative of 2*r.  So the antiderivative of the whole thing is -4*pi*r^2*(1-r^2)^(3/2)/3 minus the antiderivative of -8*pi*r*(1-r^2)^(3/2)/3; the latter is 8*pi*(1-r^2)^(5/2)/15, so the whole antiderivative is equal to -4*pi*r^2*(1-r^2)^(3/2)/3 - 8*pi*(1-r^2)^(5/2)/15.  I know that looks intimidating, but it looks a lot less so when you realize you only have to consider the difference between the values at r = 1 and r = 0; at r = 1, (1-r^2) is zero, so both terms are zero, and at r = 0, the first term is zero, and the second is equal to -8*pi/15.  The moment of inertia, in the units where the radius is 1 and the mass is 4*pi/3, is (0 - (-8*pi/15)) = 8*pi/15, which is, in our units, 2/5 the mass.  (If you're put off by the lack of units, just pretend we've been working in cm and grams - or meters and Imperial tons, or whatever else - it genuinely doesn't matter.)  (EDIT: I just realized I didn't explain why the derivative of (1-r^2)^(3/2) would be -3*r*sqrt(1-r^2).  It's called the "chain rule" - what it is is that if you know how much a quantity is changing in relation to another quantity, and how much that quantity is changing in relation to a third quantity, by multiplying the two rates of change you'll get how much the first quantity is changing in relation to the third.  In this case, as she went over in the video on derivatives, the derivative x^(3/2) with respect to x is 3*sqrt(x)/2, and the derivative of (1-t^2) with respect to t would be -2t, so you just multiply the two.)

First, there is a missing piece of information: mass. If we assume that the marble and the ring are of equal mass, then the marble would win because its mass is distributed closer to the rotational centre, giving it a lower moment of inertia. However, in the illustration it looks as if the marble and the ring are roughly the same circumference. If so, the ring would be much less massive (assuming that they are made from materials of comparable density), which would give it less inertia, and thus allow it to accelerate faster.

Dave Drader, no.  Mass doesn't matter because it cancels out - they have more inertia, but gravity's pulling harder, just like with the feather and the bowling ball.  Radius does matter - the video assumes the ring and the marble have the same radius.  If the radius of the marble were more than 1.58 that of the ring, the marble would have a greater moment of inertia in proportion to its mass, so the ring would go more quickly.

Friction is what prevents an object from moving down a ramp, not what helps move it. The reason why the objects move down the ramp is the force the gravity. The force of gravity is always straight down to the Earth's center, so the component of gravity aligned going down the ramp is what moves the object down. Friction (static or kinetic) would oppose the force of gravity. The object moves when the force of gravity aligned with the ramp is greater than friction.   Reasons why she is considering static friction but not kinetic friction:  If there is static friction, an object that rotates about an axis, such as a sphere, will not slip. Static friction gives a force of gravity. The force gravity will cause translational motion, while that initial static friction will cause rotational motion. For objects that do not have rotational motion, such as the cube, will have no affect from that initial static friction other than breaking through the threshold of friction. If there is not kinetic friction, then we won't lose energy when moving down the ramp. If there was kinetic energy, the cube will move down the ramp much slower than the ring or the sphere because more of its surface is in contact with the ramp to be affected by friction. Kinetic friction causes energy lost, so rotational energy and kinetic energy will not equal potential energy as the video shows. Also if there was kinetic friction, the results of the race would be different. The sphere is only in contact with the surface at one point, so it would have the least lost of energy from kinetic friction and will get to the bottom first.   If I made any mistakes or left out any important information, please let me know.

Aaaa-khem.   1) Coefficient of (static/sliding) friction has nothing to do with area of contact, but only material and conditions of the surfaces. So, given ring and box having equal materials, they would have equal coefficients, even if a ring have minuscule area of contact.  2) "the moment the box slips" makes no sense. The forces that drive the motion are gravity and the reaction of the ramp (also dependent on gravity). The gravity force is just constant, it doesn't increase or change.  Either gravity-induced downslope force is high enough to overcome static friction and then all objects slide, or its not, and then the box is not sliding at all (ring might slide or not - its called "rolling resistance").  There is no such coefficient of friction that would allow box sliding while the ring is forced rolling.  Think of it in this way, if you need an intuition. Any system is trying to achieve minimal energy state the most direct way possible. WHY, OH WHY would energy go into torque when sliding option is open for the ring?

***** 1) Agreed. 2) I meant "after the box begins slipping", because once it is, kinetic friction applies instead of static friction.  In the case of the box, the tangential friction force required to prevent the box from slipping is very easy to calculate: no slip means no movement, so F = ma = 0, and the gravity and friction forces must balance (in the tangential direction).  However, in the case of the ring, even if there is sufficient static friction to prevent slipping, the ring will still roll. This means that there is an acceleration in the tangential direction, which means that forces aren't balanced in the tangential direction. Since gravity is the same that it's always been, we must conclude that the friction force is smaller than the box case.  Therefore, there exists an intermediate friction force (and therefore an intermediate static friction coefficient) that allows the box to slide, but forces the ring to roll rather than slide.

TheHue's SciTech  "even if there is sufficient static friction to prevent slipping" - but that's exactly the problem. There's no sufficient static friction to prevent slippage. We know that because if there was  - the box would not slide at all.  Look, the box is sliding, therefore gravity exerts enough force on it to overcome static friction, however big it is. We see it true for the box, therefore it is true for the ring (assuming identical materials).  Even if we assume that before objects at first are somehow prevented from moving (say, we hold them in place with fingers) and then released, there still will be no  rolling.  When there's no kinetic friction, there's no rolling resistance - and rolling linear motion cannot be converted to angular momentum.  Imagine the opposite, if it helps you - you spin the ring in mid-air and let it fall on the kinetically frictionless surface. Will any of angular momentum transfer into linear motion? No. Same for the inverse situation.

TheHue's SciTech  Looked at your link. You have a logic failure there.  Let me explain. The proving/disproving of something has many ways, one of the ways is to postulate a hypothesis - "ring will roll without slipping under such conditions" - and then explore the situation under such conditions.  If the outcomes - the forces must be such and such and acceleration will be such - at least look plausible, then hypothesis, while still not proven, can be explored further.  If after postulating a hypothesis you face a break down of your system, a paradox of sorts, then your hypothesis is wrong or at the very least incompatible with the rest of presuppositions.  Now, back to your drawing, what is the sum of forces acting on the ring? The only force is gravity, in two orthogonal components. They form a right triangle, so values must follow the rule for the right triangle sides (a^2 + b^2 = c^2):  (m*g) ^2 = Ft ^2 + Fn ^2 = 1/4 * (m*g)^2 * (sin t)^2 + (m*g)^2 * (cos t)^2  Dividing both sides by (m*g)^2 we have 1 = 1/4 (sin t)^2 + (cos t)^2  Which is in contradiction with trig idendity (cos a)^2 + (sin a)^2 = 1  Thus, we conclude that proposed hypothesis would lead to impossible situation and should be rejected.

***** In my diagram, Ft is the friction force, not the tangential component of gravity. In both cases the tangential component of gravity is indeed mg sin t (it's even written inside the box on the left, albeit as "sin t mg", which isn't the best way to write it :-) ). So in both cases, the trig identity is just fine. Sorry I didn't explicitly draw the tangential component of gravity on the diagram, I thought it was implied. But it's there in the sum of forces inside the box.  Tangential component of gravity: mg sin t Fricion force: 1/2 mg sin t  If the friction force were mg sin t in the ring case, that would leave the forces on the ring balanced, and hence no acceleration of the centre of mass of the ring would be possible. Thus. the ring would either stay glued in place or spin in-place like sonic the hedgehog. Both these claims are clearly absurd (and more scientifically, the former fails to balance torques, and the latter has friction force pointing the wrong way w.r.t. the direction of motion). Hence, contradiction to your claim that the friction force must equal mg sin t.

But please, I'd really like to see your free-body diagram that shows friction equalling mg sin t, and yet the ring still having a net acceleration (rolling down the ramp).  When I invoked that friction = ma, I didn't just pull that out of thin air. That is Ft = ma, which is the result of solving the following equations**: Torque = Ft * r, Torque = I * alpha, I = mr^2, a = r * alpha. And yes, a is the acceleration of the centre of mass of the ring, which is the correct thing to use for F=ma. And the way that "a" finds its way into the Ft = ma solution is via the statement that a = r * alpha, which is also clearly true (it's the very definition of the no slip condition for a wheel/ring).  ** If you have an objection to any of these equations, or the claim that they reduce to Ft = ma, or the statement that sum(forces) = ma where a is the acceleration of the centre of mass, then that's something we can focus our discussion on.
